ticket.tag: activeresource patch "rails 3.0 beta" serialization to_json to_xml
ticket.title: ActiveResource does not serialize XML correctly
ticket.original-body:
Assuming I have
@@@ class RemoteArticle < ActiveResource::Base self.element_name = 'article' end
RemoteArticle.new.to_xml @@@
now results in:
@@@ <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <remote-article> </remote-article> @@@
the node tag name should really be article, not remote-article.
I'm hacking my way round this by making the encode method call "to_xml :root => self.class.element_name" as I see methods like update/create call encode rather than to_xml/to_json however this is not a real fix.
I'm using Rails 3.0 trunk/master from about 2 hours ago. I don't seem to recall this being an issue in beta 1 or 2.
ticket.latest-body:
Assuming I have
@@@ class RemoteArticle < ActiveResource::Base self.element_name = 'article' end
RemoteArticle.new.to_xml @@@
now results in:
@@@ <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <remote-article> </remote-article> @@@
the node tag name should really be article, not remote-article.
I'm hacking my way round this by making the encode method call "to_xml :root => self.class.element_name" as I see methods like update/create call encode rather than to_xml/to_json however this is not a real fix.
I'm using Rails 3.0 trunk/master from about 2 hours ago. I don't seem to recall this being an issue in beta 1 or 2.
ticket.original-body-html:
Assuming I have

class RemoteArticle < ActiveResource::Base
  self.element_name = 'article'
end

RemoteArticle.new.to_xml

now results in:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<remote-article>
</remote-article>

the node tag name should really be article, not remote-article.

I'm hacking my way round this by making the encode method call "to_xml :root => self.class.element_name" as I see methods like update/create call encode rather than to_xml/to_json however this is not a real fix.

I'm using Rails 3.0 trunk/master from about 2 hours ago. I don't seem to recall this being an issue in beta 1 or 2.

version.body:
Assuming I have
@@@ class RemoteArticle < ActiveResource::Base self.element_name = 'article' end
RemoteArticle.new.to_xml @@@
now results in:
@@@ <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <remote-article> </remote-article> @@@
the node tag name should really be article, not remote-article.
I'm hacking my way round this by making the encode method call "to_xml :root => self.class.element_name" as I see methods like update/create call encode rather than to_xml/to_json however this is not a real fix.
I'm using Rails 3.0 trunk/master from about 2 hours ago. I don't seem to recall this being an issue in beta 1 or 2.
version.body-html:
Assuming I have

class RemoteArticle < ActiveResource::Base
  self.element_name = 'article'
end

RemoteArticle.new.to_xml

now results in:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<remote-article>
</remote-article>

the node tag name should really be article, not remote-article.

I'm hacking my way round this by making the encode method call "to_xml :root => self.class.element_name" as I see methods like update/create call encode rather than to_xml/to_json however this is not a real fix.

I'm using Rails 3.0 trunk/master from about 2 hours ago. I don't seem to recall this being an issue in beta 1 or 2.
version.tag: activeresource "rails 3.0 beta" serialization to_xml
version.title: ActiveResource does not serialize XML correctly

version.body:
Even Rails beta 3 is working fine. Problem is in the edge version.
I introduced a major change the way to_xml works a week back. Looks like that commit is causing the error. Looking into this issue.
version.body-html:
Even Rails beta 3 is working fine. Problem is in the edge version.

I introduced a major change the way to_xml works a week back. Looks like that commit is causing the error. Looking into this issue.
version.tag: activeresource "rails 3.0 beta" serialization to_xml
version.title: ActiveResource does not serialize XML correctly

version.body:
On further analysis the commit that is causing this problem is this one.
http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/7cd1d37a51f5f53f8fc1360f886d26cabf12d969
version.body-html:
On further analysis the commit that is causing this problem is this one.

http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/7cd1d37a51f5f53f8fc1360f886d26...
version.tag: activeresource "rails 3.0 beta" serialization to_xml
version.title: ActiveResource does not serialize XML correctly

version.body:
Commit http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/7cd1d37a51f5f53f8fc1360f886d26cabf12d969 deleted following line 
self.class.format.encode(attributes, 
            {:root => self.class.element_name}.merge(options))
With that line gone there is no easy way to pass self.class.element_name as root. I would like to submit a patch for it but I do not see any easy way. Please provide how should I proceed. The way I see it there is need for to_xml method in the class. I will work on a test patch that will add a failing test. I know usually one should not directly assign a ticket to someone . However I am assigning this ticket to Jeremy because he signed off on the last commit.
version.body-html:
Commit http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/7cd1d37a51f5f53f8fc1360f886d26... deleted following line

self.class.format.encode(attributes, 
            {:root => self.class.element_name}.merge(options))

With that line gone there is no easy way to pass self.class.element_name as root.

I would like to submit a patch for it but I do not see any easy way. Please provide how should I proceed.

The way I see it there is need for to_xml method in the class.

I will work on a test patch that will add a failing test.

I know usually one should not directly assign a ticket to someone . However I am assigning this ticket to Jeremy because he signed off on the last commit.
version.tag: activeresource "rails 3.0 beta" serialization to_xml
version.title: ActiveResource does not serialize XML correctly

version.body: Doh! Needs a regression test + fix.
version.body-html: Doh! Needs a regression test + fix.
version.tag: activeresource "rails 3.0 beta" serialization to_xml
version.title: ActiveResource does not serialize XML correctly

version.body: On the patches i've made tests on ActiveResource use the methods to_xml and to_json. I refactored AMo::Name and allow element and collection attributes to be writable. Then i make ActiveRecord delegate to AMo the use of element_name and collection_name instead of managing his own copy itself. Added a few tests also.
version.body-html:
On the patches i've made tests on ActiveResource use the methods to_xml and to_json.
I refactored AMo::Name and allow element and collection attributes to be writable.
Then i make ActiveRecord delegate to AMo the use of element_name and collection_name instead of managing his own copy itself.
Added a few tests also.
version.tag: activeresource patch "rails 3.0 beta" serialization to_xml
version.title: ActiveResource does not serialize XML correctly

version.body:
Pastorino, your patch is changing the cached values. This means that every time I call human, it's going to execute this line:
ActiveSupport::Inflector.humanize(@element).freeze
And you should change the @human value if the @element changes. Consider this case:
class Post < ActiveResource::Base self.element_name = "api-post" end
Post.model_name.human #=> "Post"
You should also cache the collection using "@collection ||=".
version.body-html:
Pastorino, your patch is changing the cached values. This means that every time I call human, it's going to execute this line:

ActiveSupport::Inflector.humanize(@element).freeze

And you should change the @human value if the @element changes. Consider this case:

class Post < ActiveResource::Base
  self.element_name = "api-post"
end

Post.model_name.human #=> "Post"

You should also cache the collection using "@collection ||=".
version.tag: activeresource patch "rails 3.0 beta" serialization to_xml
version.title: ActiveResource does not serialize XML correctly

version.body: Yes, you're right on the human cache. The other one shouldn't be cached because i want to return @collection only if someone does self.collection_name = "api-posts" if it's not setted we should return the inflection thing i did. Patch again.
version.body-html:
Yes, you're right on the human cache. The other one shouldn't be cached because i want to return @collection only if someone does self.collection_name = "api-posts" if it's not setted we should return the inflection thing i did.
Patch again.

version.tag: activeresource patch "rails 3.0 beta" serialization to_json to_xml
version.title: ActiveResource does not serialize XML correctly

version.body: `ActiveModel::Name` isn't meant to be a mutable object, though. You could set and cache these on the instance itself, or instantiate and cache a new `Name` with updated values.
version.body-html: ActiveModel::Name isn't meant to be a mutable object, though. You could set and cache these on the instance itself, or instantiate and cache a new Name with updated values.

version.tag: activeresource patch "rails 3.0 beta" serialization to_json to_xml
version.title: ActiveResource does not serialize XML correctly

version.body:
Setting a custom collection name is not preserved:
@@@ ruby name.collection = 'foo' name.element = 'bar' assert_equal 'foo', name.collection # but it returns 'bars' @@@
Also, this is unneeded @@@ - attr_reader :singular, :plural, :element, :collection, :partial_path - alias_method :cache_key, :collection + attr_reader :singular, :plural, :partial_path + attr_accessor :element, :collection + alias_method :cache_key, :collection @@@ since you defined the writer methods already.
version.body-html:
Setting a custom collection name is not preserved:

name.collection = 'foo'
name.element = 'bar'
assert_equal 'foo', name.collection  # but it returns 'bars'

Also, this is unneeded

-    attr_reader :singular, :plural, :element, :collection, :partial_path
-    alias_method :cache_key, :collection
+    attr_reader   :singular, :plural, :partial_path
+    attr_accessor :element, :collection
+    alias_method  :cache_key, :collection
since you defined the writer methods already.

version.body:
This changeset includes a regression or an intentional change that should be documented.
@@@ module Foo class Bar < ActiveResource::Base end end @@@
Before the changeset, this would requests the url /bars After the changeset, this now requests the url /foo/bars
version.body-html:
This changeset includes a regression or an intentional change that should be documented.

module Foo
  class Bar < ActiveResource::Base
  end
end

Before the changeset, this would requests the url /bars
After the changeset, this now requests the url /foo/bars
